I'm grateful to our panelists for sharing their insights on how to navigate the many #mentalhealth challenges associated with #COVID19. @BCBSMA members can visit our new mental health resource center to explore options for support: https://t.co/0LLQd56ooc
"It's ok to not be ok. We're in the midst of a pandemic and it's challenging for all of us. Have compassion for yourself." - Dr. Christine Crawford
"No one should be worrying alone - there are supports and advocates out there - please don't be afraid to reach out and ask for help." - Deirdre Calvert

"Mental health services on campus and beyond are overwhelmed and inundated with referrals right now. I can't emphasize enough how important it is to reach out to the PCP for help in finding support." - Dr. Christine Crawford
Question for panelists - how do we help college age young adults who are struggling with #mentalhealth during this time?

"We're now looking inward to see how we as clinicians may be further contributing to the disparities when it comes to #mentalhealth and communities and color, including diagnosing and prescribing patterns." - Dr. Christine Crawford

On systemic #racism and how it affects patients of color: "In recent months, there have been more open discussions within the #mentalhealth field on the role clinicians have played & how we can better understand the historical context and lack of trust."- Dr. Christine Crawford

"If it gets to the point where you can't function, focus on work/school, maintain relationships, or physical health is deteriorating, you need to talk to a health care provider. #mentalhealth conditions are medical conditions & they respond to treatment!" - Dr. Christine Crawford

"We're so used to talking about all kinds of other medical issues and the help we seek out for symptoms - but it's rare someone shares their experience with #depression, medication, etc. We need to start having more of these conversations." - Dr. Christine Crawford
Question: "If you're experiencing #depression for the first time, how do you decide if it's time to find professional help? And where do you look?"
"You don't have to continue to live with fear of being judged - find a mental health professional who can work with you to heal your emotional difficulties." - Dr. Christine Crawford

"It's hard enough to have a #mentalhealth condition, but to have to struggle without the support of friends/family around you is so much more challenging. Establish a relationship with someone you feel comfortable sharing your emotional experience with." -Dr. Christine Crawford

"We're all trying to figure out this new world, so we have to be gentle on ourselves, and we shouldn't be ashamed to ask for help - we all need to show more understanding." - Deirdre Calvert MSW, LICSW @MassDPH
Question for the panelists: How do you tell someone you're not ok, when your life looks great from the outside?

"Our capacity to cope has really been challenged during the pandemic - economic instability, childcare worries, we're all trying to manage & we need to remove the stigma around mental health"- Dr. Irene Falgas-Bague, clinical psychiatrist/research scientist at @MassGeneralNews

On substance use disorder during #COVID19 - "We know recovery thrives in community and addiction thrives in isolation...so for those in treatment and recovery, this is an incredibly difficult time" - Deirdre Calvert, @MassDPH

What the clinicians are seeing right now: "Kids are feeling a tremendous sense of isolation during the pandemic. They're missing that emotional support normally found at school, and that's leading to more anxiety/depression." - child psychiatrist Dr. Christine Crawford.
Our panelists today include @BCBSMA's Dr. Ken Duckworth, a psychiatrist who's also Chief Medical Officer at @NAMICommunicate.
Rates of #anxiety and #depression are up almost 400% - this is a critical time to talk about #mentalhealth.
